Award.AwardTitle: Parents' Role in Chinese and American Children's Academic and Emotional Functioning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Chinese children are more engaged in school than are American children. It is thus not surprising that they outperform American children in the academic arena. This edge has led to recommendations that American parents adopt Chinese parents' learning-related practices. Caution is warranted, however, because Chinese children perceive their competence more negatively than do their American counterparts, which may contribute to their heightened vulnerability to poor emotional functioning as they move into adolescence. Focusing on this phase of development in China and the United States, this project has three major aims: (1) Identify whether the heightened academic and dampened emotional functioning of Chinese (vs. American) children is due, in part, to the heightened reactivity of the glucocorticoid hormone cortisol in the face of challenge; (2) elucidate the role of parents' learning-related socialization practices in the differences between Chinese and American children's academic and emotional functioning; (3) determine why Chinese and American parents use different learning-related socialization practices, with attention to the effect of parents' learning-related beliefs. To investigate these aims, children entering adolescence and their mothers in China and the United States will participate in a three-wave project spanning a one-year period. A key strength of the project is its use of observations, self-reports, and biological assessments in different contexts (e.g., before and after challenge).

Effective policies and programs aimed at what has been labelled America's "vanishing potential" require a sophisticated understanding of the forces that contribute to children's learning. This project will be informative as to whether and how best practices from China and the United States may be combined to optimize academic and emotional functioning among children. It will be the first to examine whether Chinese children's academic edge over American children may come at an emotional cost due to heightened biological reactivity to challenge. Moreover, the concern with elucidating the role of parents' learning-related practices in the differences in Chinese and American children's academic and emotional functioning moves beyond the largely descriptive research in this area to identifying underlying mechanisms. Because there is variability among parents within China and the United States in their learning-related practices, the project will provide insight into the effects of such practices within the two countries. In doing so, it will allow for an evaluation of the similarity of the socialization process in the two, an issue over which there is controversy. Together these advances will shape models of socialization which have an almost exclusively American foundation. Despite the import of research efforts involving multiple countries, such efforts are relatively rare. Thus, the proposed research will provide unique training opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is increasing concern that American children are not achieving at their full potential. A particular point of risk is early adolescence when American children often come to view school as less valuable, becoming less engaged (e.g., for example paying less attention in class) over time as well. Research in China does not find such a trend: Chinese children continue to see school as valuable across early adolescence, maintaining their engagement. Because children’s engagement in school plays a role in their achievement, the edge that Chinese children have over their American counterparts during early adolescence may underlie their edge in achievement in a variety of subjects. One of the goals of the current research was to elucidate why the movement away from school evident in the United States during early adolescence is not evident in China. This is of import in providing insight into how to support American children during this phase of development.

In 1928, Margaret Mead argued that culture may shape how adolescence is viewed, ultimately determining how children navigate this phase of development. Drawing from this idea, we examined the extent to which American and Chinese children and their mothers hold different conceptions of adolescence. Our key hypothesis, based on prior research in the United States, was that Americans see adolescence as a time of individuation from parents in which children move away from parents – and the endeavors they value – toward peers. In contrast, in China where interdependence is often valued more than independence, emphasis is placed on filial piety, which entails children repaying the family for their efforts in raising them, bringing honor to the family, and making sacrifices for the family. Thus, children’s progress toward maturity may be defined in part by their fulfilling their responsibilities to parents often through doing well in school. Moreover, there is a dearth of extracurricular activities and discouragement of informal peer cliques during early in China.  

To examine whether adolescence is viewed differently in the United States and China, we had 394 young adolescents and their mothers in the United States and China complete both open-ended (i.e., they listed the attributes of a typical young teen) and close-ended (i.e., the rated to what extent a variety of behaviors and attitudes were more or less characteristic of teens versus younger children). Overall, American adolescents and their mothers characterized teens as attempting to establish their independence by moving away from their parents and toward their peers more than did Chinese adolescents. Specifically, Americans were more likely than their Chinese counterparts to see teens (vs. younger children) as (a) individuating more from parents through, for example, demanding to make their own decisions, (b) feeling less responsible to parents (e.g., not feeling obligated to follow their parents wishes), (c) being more oriented toward peers (e.g., wanting to spend all of their free time with friends), and (d) disengaging more from school (e.g., not paying attention in class).

Notably, these ideas about adolescence appear to be instrumental in adolescents’ engagement in school over early adolescence, accounting for differences between American and Chinese adolescents. Specifically, the more adolescents in both China and the United States saw teens (vs. younger children) as feeling less responsible to their parents and disengaging more from school, the more their engagement in school declined from seventh to eighth grade. Notably, the tendency for American (vs. Chinese) adolescents to view adolescence as a time of feeling less responsible and disengaging from school accounted for the tendency for American but not Chinese adolescents’ engagement to decrease over early adolescence.
